utterances: Pat Quinn is a totally and completely undisciplined individual.
He almost created shambles in that department.
He was dismissed, should have been dismissed.
Governor Quinn counters that he was an effective revenue director.
He punches back at Hynes' competency with an ad of his own, charging the comptroller mismanaged his oversight of cemeteries after a historic black graveyard near Chicago was desecrated.
(Soundbite of political ad)
Unidentified Man #1: Hundreds of bodies dug up, the graves resold, grieving families unsure where their loved ones are buried.
It was Dan Hynes' job to regulate our cemeteries, but...
Hynes says Quinn is distorting his record.
Democrats took the governor seat in 2002 after a corruption scandal ended more than a quarter of a century of Republican rule in Illinois.
Unidentified Man #2: Meet the Republicans for governor next on ""Chicago Tonight.
There are six Republicans seeking to capitalize on the Blagojevich scandal, though.
In a state that's seen as moderate, all are against abortion, gay marriage and civil unions.
Most would lift the state's moratorium on the death penalty and four have signed a pledge not to raise taxes.
In most independent polls, the race among Republicans is close.
One candidate, the former head of the Illinois GOP, was slammed in an internal Republican Party probe for ethical missteps, but he has dominated the airways with commercials.
It's an old commercial for a Democrat that has come to haunt one of the Republicans.
State Senator Kirk Dillard appeared in an ad for his former state Senate colleague, Barack Obama, when he ran for president.
Dillard says he did not endorse Obama, but they worked together on ethics reform.
People are sick and tired of politicized partisan politics.
And I disagree with Barack Obama on 95 percent of what he does, but on ethics, I agree with him.
Illinois moved its primary date up to February to help influence the 2008 presidential election.
But with no such draw this time, turnout may be an issue.
Cold wintry weather may be a big obstacle for candidates hoping to claim victory tomorrow.
Cheryl Corley, NPR News, Chicago.
For weeks now, the debate centered on whether to send in more troops as the top U.S.
commander, General Stanley McChrystal, favors, or whether to scale back the mission, something Vice President Joe Biden is set to support.
Now, military officers, analysts and politicians here in Washington regard McChrystal as a highly talented and courageous leader.
And when he was tapped to fill the top military post in Afghanistan, the Senate Armed Services Committee confirmed him unanimously.
The NFL player draft takes place later this month in Nashville, home to the Tennessee Titans.
But the city, in preparing to receive huge crowds from out of town, made a misstep.
Officials decided to remove rows of cherry trees to make room for an outdoor stage.
Tony Gonzalez of member station WPLN reports self-described tree-huggers in the city are taking action.
Fellow tree-huggers and fellow Loraxes, we are gathered as a group of citizens committed to change.
Jim Gregory, on the steps of Nashville City Hall, riles up a couple dozen defenders of the cherry trees.
And we are here today because all of us have witnessed the largest trees in our city be cut down in our neighborhood without a single thing we can do.
Gregory is well-known here as the Lorax of Nashville, an homage to the Dr. Seuss character who, all by himself, fought and failed to protect a forest.
In Nashville, though, Jim Gregory is far from being alone.
Some 66,000 people signed an online petition to try to stop the removal.
At first, the city planned to chop down 21 trees.
And then word got out.
The head of the city tourism agency apologized.
The mayor backtracked, eventually deciding to move and replant 10 trees.
You know, it just kind of felt like they were pulling a fast one on us.
Heather Lose is editor of Tennessee Conservationist magazine.
Her father designed Nashville's Riverfront Park, a brick walkway with tiered seating for concerts.
The park overlooks the Cumberland River with the Titans football stadium on the opposite bank.
Lose says the outrage is about more than a couple rows of trees.
It's because many more trees have already been chopped down to make way for housing.
I think we're all a little chapped right now.
You know, we're all having this experience as Nashvillians where you're driving home, and you round a curve, and they have clear-cut a whole beautiful wooded lot.
Nashville has lost thousands of trees in its development boom.
Activists documented more than a hundred construction sites that ignored rules meant to protect the canopy.
So people are on guard.
Add to that Nashville's rise as a red-hot tourist destination.
We made this city cool.
We made this city a place that people want to come.
(SOUNDBITE OF PEOPLE YELLING)
Down by the riverfront, rowdy tourists ride on rolling taverns.
Drinks flow.
Music blares.
They putter past the cherry trees.
More than a thousand have been planted citywide since the 1980s.
That's when the consulate general of Japan set up office here thanks to Tennessee's business ties with the likes of Nissan and Bridgestone.
There's also an annual Cherry Blossom Festival, this year just two weeks before the draft.
Terri Didato, visiting from Panama City, Fla., makes a point to pose for a photo in front of the trees.
The trees are beautiful.
I love all the blooms.
We don't get to see this kind of stuff in Panama City.
We got pine trees (laughter).
She glances across the water to the stadium.
I mean, I love the NFL.
They don't need to be messing with this over here, I mean, in my opinion, or cutting down these beautiful trees.
Those trees have been uprooted now.
Arborists note bloom time is a terrible time for a transplant.
These trees may not survive.
The city tourism agency and the NFL have now promised to plant more than 200 additional trees but only after the league's draft is done.
For NPR News, I'm Tony Gonzalez in Nashville.
From NPR News, it's Day to Day.

And today's Wall Street Journal reports that General Motors is considering thousands of layoffs of white collar workers and possibly selling off some unprofitable brands, all in an effort to stop hemorrhaging money, billions of dollars worth.
Marketplace's Bob Moon joins us now with more.
And Bob, tell us first about the layoffs.
What kinds of cuts is GM thinking about?
Madeleine, GM has already cut white-collar jobs to 32,000 last year from 44,000 at the start of the new millennium.
And they are continuing to look at all sorts of cost-saving measures.
The options for workforce cuts are aren't specified in this Wall Street Journal article, but they're supposed to be presented to GM's board of directors early next month.
And what about this news that it might cut some of its brands?
It has a lot of brands, right?
A lot of car brands.
That's right.
It has eight of them.
It might be easier to start off with what brands they would not be dropping.
GM considers Chevrolet and Cadillac to be its core business, so they would appear to be safe.
Although, Cadillac accounts to just over five percent of GM's total sales, not a lot.
Chevrolet by comparison provided almost 60 percent of the company's sales last year.
Now that said, GM is all ready trying to find a buyer for its money-losing and gas-guzzling Hummer division.
Its European market brand, Saab, would be a likely candidate for sale.
Its domestic Buick brand has contributed the least to GM's bottom line, so that could be a target.
Analysts say Saturn also has had some trouble finding a consistent brand identity within the GM fold.
Well, this is a massive company, obviously, how does a company this big turn itself around and turn itself around quickly?
That's a really good question.
Like a battleship, it turns up.
It's not like GM has been dealing with these problems just since yesterday.
Let me play you a comment that CEO Rick Wagoner made to GM shareholders on this very topic.
The most challenging and important issue that we face now is getting GM North America, our biggest business unit, turned around and back into a profitable position.
That was the head of GM addressing shareholders exactly three years ago.
Now what's happened since then is that GM saw a lot of profitability in its SUVs and bigger models up until the oil market got out of control in the past year, year and a half.
The companies - not just GM but automakers in general - enjoyed big markups for those models, and so they were inclined to put a lot of their production where the money was.
And now that they're retooling and have to retool, they're very reluctant to do that fast.
They learned that lesson the hard way back in the 1970s and '80s when they did focus on reducing emissions and fuel consumption.

They achieved that, but it came at the expense of things like style, and performance, and quality, and reliability, and they lost customers because of it, so they're being very careful in their redesigns this time around.
Today, the second large recall this month of toys made in China.
Mattel recalled more than nine million toys just two weeks after its subsidiary, Fisher-Price, announced a big recall because of lead paint.
Mattel's announcement came shortly after a high-end toiletries company, Gilchrist & Soames, said it is recalling tainted toothpaste.
In a few minutes, we'll talk to a pediatrician about what to look for when buying toys.
First, here is NPR's Adam Davidson on today's recalls.
Mattel actually announced two separate recalls today.
The first was the largest.
The nine million recalled toys contained powerful magnets.
If a child swallows more than one, the magnets can wreak havoc on the intestines.
Mattel CEO Bob Eckert said that these toys happened to be made in China, but the recall was because of a design problem.
This is not a manufacturing issue when we talk about magnets.
In this case, the Chinese manufacturer did everything right.
The recall covers a variety of brand names including Barbie, Batman and Doggie Day Care.
Today's second recall is much smaller, just over 200,000 toys and does involve a Chinese manufacturer's error.
Lead paint was found on toy cars with a Sarge brand.
Mattel's Eckert says the toys were made in one factory in China, but some parts in the toy cars were painted by a Chinese subcontractor.
The subcontractor violated the procedures and the rules and for whatever reason, used the wrong paint.
Eckert says these two recalls will cost the company around $30 million but he's confident that Mattel's brand image will not be permanently tarnished.
I'm here to assure parents that we understand the problems, we've isolated the problems and we've taken corrective actions.
As far as crisis management 101, they're doing a pretty good job.
